Thank you @RevDrBarber for penning this op-ed with me. Providing your grace, insight, and strength into these words. Let’s keep fighting.

A month ago, those who prepare our food, deliver our packages, drive our buses, and clean our offices were called “service workers.”

Now, they are called “essential workers.” 

They’ve been essential all along. It’s time we acknowledge them as such.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/04/27/pandemic-changed-our-definition-essential-will-we-act-what-we-learned/

Government can’t really close or open the economy; the economy is human action. What government can do is impede or facilitate people’s ability to adapt to change. More centralized decision making means less use of dispersed knowledge. Less use of knowledge means worse outcomes.

Six years later, we cannot forget #Flint. What happened to my hometown is not an anomaly—rather, it’s a warning to the rest of the country that we must get serious about better protecting public health & addressing the injustices that we see in society.

While I’m grateful Congress acted to replace lead pipes & expand health care for residents, more can be done. Including relief from high water bills, fund Flint registry & invest in Flint Community Schools, where children exposed to lead could benefit from additional support.

I'm proud to have secured funding in the CARES Act for rural hospitals & Rural Healthcare Clinics in #TX25 – Ascension Seton Highland Lakes and Baylor Scott & White Medical Center-Marble Falls each received over $84K so they can keep taking care of Texans.

Flint is strong. We are resilient. But now with the coronavirus pandemic, Flint faces a crisis on top of a crisis. Back-to-back public health emergencies have contributed to a unique crisis that requires further action to support families.

This past weekend, my hometown marked the sixth anniversary of the #FlintWaterCrisis. Access to clean & affordable drinking water should be a right for all. This is a simple change that doesn’t cost the federal govt and taxpayers $ but can have a large impact on student learning and easing the economic burden families facing this unprecedented challenge. 7/9

Currently, if 529 account withdrawals are not used for qualified education expenses or tuition for elementary or secondary schools, they are subject to state and federal income taxes and an additional 10% federal tax penalty on earnings of the account. 6/9

529 plans were recently expanded to cover high school & elementary school tuition. Especially during this unique time, it is important to allow families to use money that has been set aside for their kid’s education, without being taxed & penalized by the federal government. 5/9

What are 529 plans? A 529 plan is a tax-advantaged savings plan designed to encourage saving for future education costs. It is like a retirement account for qualified education expenses. Typically, these plans have been used for higher education costs, like college tuition. 4/9

Parents & schools are facing unique challenges while trying to educate our children from home. These can range from lack of economic resources to lack of tools necessary for distance education. Congress should change 529 plans to help students & families ease the burden. 3/9
#coronavirus has impacted millions of school children. Families are educating their children from home because schools are closed. 2/9

Congress should act to allow 529 education savings plans to cover expenses related to learning from home. See my full letter to Congressional leadership. 1/9 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EWorXxuXkAE5vs5.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EWorXxzX0AIOZ3I.jpg

5. Place an added emphasis on quality standards for long-term care that protects healthcare workers, emphasizes data gathering, and provides adequate testing to protect both workers and residents.

My staff and I are continuing to serve #MD05 constituents during this pandemic. Please visit my website at  https://hoyer.house.gov/ for additional information or call one of my district offices for further assistance.
MEALS FOR STUDENTS: Daily meals are available to students in Maryland while schools are closed. Click here to find a distribution site near you: https://mars.msde.maryland.gov/mars_sitesearch/
FOOD ASSISTANCE: @MDFoodBank & @foodbankmetrodc have set up food distribution sites and pantries around #MD05. Visit https://mdfoodbank.org/ & https://www.capitalareafoodbank.org/ to learn more.

UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE: @MD_Labor has launched a portal for Marylanders to apply for unemployment insurance. Congress provided an additional $600/week in assistance & contract workers, the self-employed, & gig economy workers can apply for benefits. https://www.dllr.state.md.us/employment/unemployment.shtml

UTILITIES: Utility companies are prohibited from disconnecting or charging late fees on electric, gas, water, sewage, phone, cable, and internet service during this crisis. @PepcoConnect & @somdelectric are available to assist in answering questions regarding late payments.

MORTAGE RELIEF: The state of Maryland has prohibited foreclosures during this pandemic. More information about mortgage relief can be found on my website: https://hoyer.house.gov/content/protecting-yourself-coronavirus

RENT: Landlords are not allowed to pursue evictions during this public health crisis. More information is available from @BrianFrosh here: http://www.marylandattorneygeneral.gov/Pages/CPD/landlords.aspx

May 1 is quickly approaching, and I know that many Marylanders are experiencing severe financial hardship because of the coronavirus. In this thread you’ll find information about financial assistance available in MD.
